key_title: Key to the species of Typha

Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Typhaceae

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Typhaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Conn, B.J. (1994). Typhaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Female part of inflorescence cinnamon- or chestnut-brown; bracts usually present in the female part of the inflorescence; stigmas linear to narrowly obovate, acuminate, markedly concave transversely, not fleshy; leaves biconvex in cross-section; pollen shed as single grains

Female part of inflorescence dark red-brown to black-brown; bracts absent from the female part of the inflorescence; stigmas narrowly obovate to obovate, ± flat and fleshy; leaves almost flat in cross-section; pollen shed in tetrads

Stigmas linear; mature female part of inflorescence 0.5–2 cm diam., length 6–20 (–40) times diam., cinnamon-brown; male and female ?spikes? separated by (0.5?) 2–5.5 cm; bracts of female part of inflorescence numerous and broadly spathulate; sheaths of upper leaves not auriculate or only the uppermost 1 or 2 leaves distinctly auriculate; leaves green, usually 4–10 mm wide; plants 1–2 m high

Stigmas narrowly ovate or narrowly obovate; mature female part of inflorescence 1–3 cm diam., length 5–10 (–18) times diam., chestnut-brown; male and female ?spikes? unseparated or separated by up to 2 (–6) cm; bracts of female part of inflorescence few or sometimes apparently absent, narrowly spathulate; sheaths of the 2–4 uppermost leaves usually distinctly auriculate; leaves bluish-green, usually 6–20 mm wide; plants 2–3 m high
